Posts.Content: Mar 6, 2009 05:02PM peeps1111 wrote: Hi: Congratulations to you, Binney!  No one is more deserving of that award.  I believe you are one of the main reasons that I don't have lymphedema.  I know we're never really safe from it but with the knowledge and help that you've given me, I feel I am armed for battle against it for the rest of my life. Peeps
Posts.Title: CONGRATS TO OUR DR. BINNEY! OneBadBoob gracejon

Posts.Content: Oct 16, 2008 07:23AM peeps1111 wrote: Hi: I got a 2nd opinion at Dana Farber in Boston.  They just called the other hospital and had them sent over.  It actually changed the grade of cancer from 2 to 2/3 so it does make a difference. Peeps DX 6/20/08, ER+,PR-,HER2-,1/2 nodes positive, Grade 2/3, Oncotype 20

Kathy:  I don't know about hot flashes but wellbutrin is supposed to be one of the few antidepressants that do not affect libido. Peeps

Posts.Content: Feb 15, 2009 10:16AM peeps1111 wrote: Hi Talk2Me: That is common, to lose your eyelashes a few weeks after the last TC.  It is definitely the chemo, not the rads.  I finished rads last week.  I had my last TC on 11/20 and my hair is just starting to grow.  Fortunately I did not lose my eyebrows and eyelashes. Peeps
Posts.Title: February 2009 rads group - all aboard!! Lories sobx

Posts.Content: Feb 16, 2009 07:12PM peeps1111 wrote: Soprano: Yes, this happened to me too.  And no one told me ahead of time, just when they went to do it. X-rays once a week, usually the day before I saw the dr. Peeps
Posts.Title: February 2009 rads group - all aboard!! Lories sobx

Posts.Content: Feb 16, 2009 01:50PM peeps1111 wrote: Hi Kari: Your onc is wrong.  You can prevent lymphedema or at least prevent it from becoming a life-long problem.  I had rads to my breast and axilla and was given (because I asked) a prescription for pt.  I found a great lymphedema-trained pt and I go twice a week.    I also swim but I've been doing that for 10 yrs. There was a study done which you may want to print out and give to your onc.  If you go to www.sciencedaily.com and do a search on "lymphedema physical therapy", you will find it. Peeps
Posts.Title: February 2009 rads group - all aboard!! Lories sobx

Posts.Content: Feb 13, 2009 06:10PM peeps1111 wrote: Hi: I am currently seeing a physical therapist who specializes in lymphedema.  I am seeing her to prevent lymphedema and she told me that in the future, the first sign of lymphedema is if your ring gets too tight. Peeps
Posts.Title: Trouble wearing ring on SNB side? mom2two KatherineA

Posts.Content: Dec 7, 2008 01:16PM peeps1111 wrote: Hi: I think I remember several years ago I checked into natural remedies for warts and tea tree oil was recommended.  You might want to check into it.  I've been using tea tree oil on my fingernails and toenails since chemo because the oncologist said I'd get "ratty" nails.  I haven't had a problem yet with my nails but maybe I wouldn't have had that anyways.  Peeps
Posts.Title: looking for advice from you LE experts... junie Binney4

Posts.Content: Nov 6, 2008 02:07PM peeps1111 wrote: Hi: Some people have posted about brushng tea tree oil on their nails so they won't have problems.  I have done it and haven't had any problems with my nails yet after 3 TC's but maybe I wouldn't have had any problems anyways.  What I'd like to know is, has anyone who has used the tea tree oil ended up with the nail problems anyways? Peeps
Posts.Title: Finger/fingernail problems? How common? Texas357 Texas357

Posts.Content: Jan 9, 2009 12:24AM peeps1111 wrote: Lisa: I had the same situation, but chose to make the drive to Dana Farber in Boston in spite of the long distance.  I am happy so far that I did.  I see my rad onc once a week and he is very involved in my treatment.  11 down, 23 to go! Peeps
Posts.Title: How important is your rad. oncologist? LisaF LisaF

Posts.Content: Oct 10, 2008 10:23AM peeps1111 wrote: Loved the story about the pantyliner, you made my day!  Maybe I'm just having a "roid" rage day from my decaodron, had my 2nd chemo yesterday but what's with all the curiosioty of people wanting to see my bald head now that my hair fell out?  I find it aggravating.  I am comfortable with it, didn't cry or anything when it fell out, had a great experience with a friend buzzing it for me but I don't feel like it's a badge of honor something that I want to show off.  Any good comebacks for people (friends???)  who want to see it and I don't feel like showing it to them?   Peeps
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Oct 11, 2008 07:11PM peeps1111 wrote: Hi: Feeling ok, thanks to all of you.  Today a bad day, wicked headache probably from the Neulasta shot yesterday, then my laptop crashed.  My brother-in-law lent me his spare though, he knows how much I need it.  He was married to my sister who died of lung cancer 6 yrs. ago and he knows all about the chemo and misery, so fortunately he came to my rescue and I am back in business.  Did a little walk with the dog.  Actually wore my wig out with a hat on when I walked the dog.  H said it looked ok.  You guys are the best! Peeps
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Oct 10, 2008 08:11PM peeps1111 wrote: I can't get a break!  I decided not to go back to the wig place because I didn't like the lady and really didn't want her buzzing my head.  I didn't know how I'd react and had wanted to be with a friend instead of a stranger.  She told me I had to wait for my hair to fall out before styling the wig after I driven all the way out there (over an hr.) after they said it was ready.  So I called a friend whose cousin said she could style it.  She's been busy every time I ask.  The wig is sitting in my laundry basket looking like a wild mophead.  So today I decided I'd get my ears pierced so I wouldn't look so manly.  I go to the mall and no one is at the Piercing Pagoda, so the security guard pages the person, no one shows, so some woman pages her, she finally shows up and says I need a friggin' driver's license to get my ears pierced.  I said it was in the car and I wasn't walking all the way back out to get it.  But she said she needed it for info.  I'm 54 years old and I need a driver's license???  So I said f--- it and left.  H is asking why I'm not wearing a wig.  I wouldn't wear it in the house anyways.  He told me I looked like a guy when I went for a walk with my friend.  Oh brother. Got my shot today and still feeling fine. When I told my onc that a lot of people thought TC2 was the worst one, she said, "well at least you know what to expect".  Then she asked me which day last time I landed in the ER with the constipation issues and I said, "Day 7" so she booked me an appt. with her on day 7 this time.  She seemed to think that my body would react the same to TC2 as TC1. Peeps
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Sep 24, 2008 03:01AM peeps1111 wrote: Jenn46: I am from Plymouth, So. Shore too.  I guess I spoke too soon.  I landed at the ER today with horrible abdominal pains.  I had a uterine tract infection, constipation and slight colits.  I was there 6 hrs.  They did a CT scan and wanted to keep me overnight but I finally escaped with two antibiotics.  So much for management of this cruel disease!  Peeps
Posts.Title: Anyone starting chemo in October 08? SuzyWillKickThis unique

Posts.Content: Oct 2, 2008 09:29PM peeps1111 wrote: Hopeful: My problem was that I followed the directions given to me for difficulty managing side effects and never really got to speak with a dr.  My dr. was off that day.  I never should have been sent to the ER since it was a weekday and should have been seen in the cancer center.  I didn't have anyone with me as I drove myself.  My youngest sister died of lung cancer several years ago and I am reluctant to put anyone in my family through this again, all the treatment appts., etc., plus the sister that died was the only one nearby.  So I only ask people if I really need them.  My friends have been awesome.   I did write a letter today to the hospital detailing my ER visit.  My oncologist encouraged me to do so in the hope that it will change the way chemo recipients are treated. My hair started falling out today, day 16.  I wonder if I can keep some of it for a few more days. My throat feels weird too, a really bad taste in the back of my throat, wondering if it is the thrush as I'm on two antibiotics.  I was going to call today but I hate the thought of going back in there and waiting around.  I guess I'll have to call tomorrow.  I've been ldoing a few home remedies for that but haven't had much luck yet clearing it up.  Peeps
Posts.Title: Anyone starting chemo in October 08? SuzyWillKickThis unique

Posts.Content: Oct 13, 2008 03:14PM peeps1111 wrote: Hi: This is the worst day ever.  I had my 2nd chemo last Thursday.  Today stuck on the toilet for over an hr.  I'll spare the gory details but I was alone and you wouldn't believe what I had to do in order to temporarily fix the situation til I could get to the drug store, ugh.  On the first chemo I ended up in the ER on the 7th day, today was only the 5th day, a holiday and wasn't about to go there again.  I'm ok now but I haven't even started the anti-nauseau, Zophran, which is what caused it last time.  The only thing I was on was whatever was in the IV and I took a couple of Vicodins the last couple of days because of the headache.  I went off the decadron Sat. and I've been on Colace, Sennecot, and Milk of Magnesia since last Thursday.  What else could I possibly do, geez?  Good luck to all of you this week, hope it goes better for you! Peeps
Posts.Title: Anyone starting chemo in October 08? SuzyWillKickThis unique

Posts.Content: Oct 21, 2008 11:20PM peeps1111 wrote: Mother78: Good luck with your mother.  I hope she does fine.  The waiting is the hardest part.  It's so good to start getting the treatments done.  Let us know how she does.  The grade rating is how aggressive the tumor is. Peeps
Posts.Title: Anyone starting chemo in October 08? SuzyWillKickThis unique

Posts.Content: Nov 7, 2008 07:46PM peeps1111 wrote: Ebann: Yes, I like my pierced ears, but can't wait til the 6 weeks is up and can wear dangly ones.  I'm glad I'm still fuzzy too and not completely bald.  It's not bad at all and I never cried when I lost my hair.  I'm so used to it now but my head gets cold. Fammy:  Don't be so hard on yourself.  What your body tolerates is beyond your control.  You just have to listen to it.  I think every 3 weeks is good, at least I like having over a week of feeling good. That way you can make plans and have something to look forward to when you do feel good. Peeps
Posts.Title: Anyone starting chemo in October 08? SuzyWillKickThis unique

Posts.Content: Nov 25, 2008 08:49AM peeps1111 wrote: Hi: Hope this thread is so quiet because everyone is having little or no SE's.  I'm sure everyone is busy with Thanksgiving prep too.  I finished my 4th and last TC on 11/20 and haven't bounced back like I usually do.  But it's over and onto rads. TNT: Thanks for the tip on the heavenly hats.  My friend teases me.  I am really getting into the hats.  She was always the big shopper, I never was.  Now I'm a fashion "hat" maven lol. I will most likely have "metal" mouth for Thanksgiving but will be happy to see my DS whom I haven't seen since Aug.  He has not seen my new fuzzy "do" except for a picture.  I feel very emotional the last few days, crying at the drop of a hat.  I used to think that it was the decadron but I've been off the decadron for a couple of days now. Peeps
Posts.Title: Anyone starting chemo in October 08? SuzyWillKickThis unique

Posts.Content: Sep 27, 2008 01:58PM peeps1111 wrote: Boursheid: My first TC was 9/17.  My 2nd one is 10/9.  Thanks. Peeps
Posts.Title: Anyone starting chemo in October 08? SuzyWillKickThis unique

Posts.Content: Sep 28, 2008 10:24AM peeps1111 wrote: Hi: Forgot to say that someone here had recommended to get the neulasta shot in my stomach so I asked the nurse for that and she did.  I think it was the first time she heard that request but she said it made sense. Peeps
Posts.Title: Anyone starting chemo in October 08? SuzyWillKickThis unique

Posts.Content: Oct 10, 2008 10:34AM peeps1111 wrote: Jenn: Thanks, had my 2nd TC yesterday, so far so good.  A few vein issues, strange.  The first time I had TC, the nurse said the IV had to be between my hand and my elbow.  Yesterday the nurse was putting it in my hand and when I asked her about it, she said, "taxotere is tough on the veins so we don't like to use the hand in case it leaks out, it can cause tissue damage".  I said, "great, I'm lefthanded", and she said not to worry, unbelievable. Last week before this chemo, I went to NY to visit a friend, a great trip, 6 great days.  Yesterday my childhood friend came to chemo with me and we caught up and had a ball.  She brought dinner too so a nice touch.  Some friends instinctively know what to do! Hope you did well on yours.  Feeling good today,  Last time on my first chemo, the worst side effects were headache and constipation so I am using more things to ward those off, today the Neulasta shot and see how that goes. Got my hair buzzed Monday.  I'm ok with that so far, hey, it's hat season and everyone will be wearing hats, it's getting so cold! Peeps
Posts.Title: Anyone starting chemo in October 08? SuzyWillKickThis unique

Posts.Content: Sep 23, 2008 03:12AM peeps1111 wrote: Jenn46: I am from Mass. too.  Just stopped in on this thread to wish you all luck.  I started chemo (TC) last Wed. and I don't know if I'm just lucky so far or really "managing" the side effects.  But the things I found helpful were the sleeping pills while on Decadron, the Claritin after the Neulasta shot (no bone pain at all), don't wait to be nauseous to start the nausea meds, just do it!  I was never one for drugs but in this case, I just want to get through it.  I rotate the pain meds. for my horrible headache, one Motrin, then 4 hrs. later one Vicodin or a half one.  I took a 1/2 decadron the day after they said to stop that too, just to taper myself off.  Also started a laxative the night before chemo to ward off constipation.  All this advice I got here.  You have to know your own body and just tweak all the advice to suit your needs.  I was very careful about the Vicodin and the sleeping pills and just try to minimize the discomfort of the SE's.  I do have the "metal" mouth today, nothing tastes good but I've continued to walk 2-1/2 miles every day and swim every other day.  Went to order the wig two days after chemo and went sailing on Sat. I was really scared before I started.  The anticipation was worse than anything else.  Peeps
Posts.Title: Anyone starting chemo in October 08? SuzyWillKickThis unique

Posts.Content: Sep 27, 2008 11:45PM peeps1111 wrote: Fammy: The nurse that gave me the Neulasta shot recommended the Claritin.  She said it's because your body is having an allergic reaction to it.  I took it and had no bone pain, just a headache.  I'm wondering if your body starts to react before you take the Claritin, if it's as effective. Peeps

Posts.Content: Oct 16, 2008 10:16PM peeps1111 wrote: threegirlsm: I have a headache on days 3-5 after the chemo but I keep drinking my coffee even though it doesn't taste that good.  I think it's from the shot because I don't have it the first or 2nd day.  Peeps
Posts.Title: Anyone starting chemo in October 08? SuzyWillKickThis unique

Posts.Content: Nov 2, 2008 12:36AM peeps1111 wrote: Hi Unique: No, no gas.  No bm today either so tomorrow maybe I'll resort to that liquid dynamite that my dr. gave me last time and I was afraid to take.  Just took my claritin tonight, forgot earlier, then got chest tightness.  Better day than I thought today, just a headache and no appetite.  Went for a walk with the dog too. Glad you had some Halloween fun!  I am so happy that I only have one more TC to go, yeah!  Hope everyone has an SE free weekend.  Enjoy the extra hour of sleep! Peeps
Posts.Title: Anyone starting chemo in October 08? SuzyWillKickThis unique

Posts.Content: Nov 3, 2008 10:10PM peeps1111 wrote: Bluedasher:  I'm sure you will be much better next week, stay positive, you will be on your trip without a doubt! Suzy:  So sorry to hear of your troubles, hope you feel better. My onc was going to give me the flu shot on the day of my 3rd chemo which I thought was bizarre.  I wanted to get it around the 2nd-3rd week after no. 2.  I ended up not saying anything because I was going to a playoff game right after my chem infusion and didn't want to risk not feeling well. So I'll ask for it the day of my last chemo, 11/20. Peeps
Posts.Title: Anyone starting chemo in October 08? SuzyWillKickThis unique

Posts.Content: Nov 6, 2008 07:06PM peeps1111 wrote: Hi: Speaking of Biotene mouthwash, talk about chemobrain.  I got up in the middle of the night to go to the bathroom and didn't turn on the light.  Decided to rinse with the mouthwash since I was there.  Didn't turn the light on and instead of the mouthwash, I grabbed the antiseptic with which I'm supposed to wash my newly-pierced ears (did it to counteract the baldness) and slugged a mouthful of it.  Wow, was I surprised, lol! Peeps
Posts.Title: Anyone starting chemo in October 08? SuzyWillKickThis unique

Posts.Content: Nov 10, 2008 09:23PM peeps1111 wrote: Cheryl: I think the nausea meds are much more effective than they used to be.  I only had taxotere and cytoxan but I never had any nausea.  I had no bone pain, or fatigue either, only a bad headache for a couple of days and issues with constipation.  I have many more good days than bad days and found that my fear of the chemo was worse than the chemo.  I think they have come a long way in medication to minimize side effects.  I am basing this on what my sister went through with her chemo 7 yrs. ago.  Although I am not a big fan of meds., this time I am doing everything I can to make my life normal.  Sorry I have no experience with carboplatin but just wanted to wish you well. I pray and hope you have an easy time of it. peeps
Posts.Title: Anyone starting chemo in October 08? SuzyWillKickThis unique

Posts.Content: Oct 31, 2008 08:34PM peeps1111 wrote: Hi: Just checking in, some abdominal pain today, unusual, didn't get that til at least the 3rd day on the first 2 TC's..  Went in for my neunasty shot today and the receptionist says I'm not in the computer.  So the one next to her says to me, "What do you THINK you're here for?"  I said, "I KNOW I'm here for my neulasta shot.  Then had to wait for 45 mins. for it.  Tired of getting treated like a moron.  Yesterday I tried to make an appt. for my last chemo and the receptionist said  I had an appt. with onc next week and couldn't make it til then.  I said, "I always make it when I leave".  Geez, no wonder you have to wait so long for every damn thing when they're micromanaging like that.  Why can't they just make an appt. when they know you have to have it?  How about a little common sense?  No wonder they take 2-1/2 hrs. to call you back when you call the hotline, when they're wasting time on that no-brainer stuff.   Rant, rant, rant. I am doing RADS after chemo's done so I'm trying to get into the Rhode Island Hospital 3-1/2 week new trial instead of the 6-1/2 week usual one.  I just want all this to be over.  I'd rather drive the 1-1/2 hrs. to RI than do the 10 min. drive here for 6-1/2 weeks.  Going to RI for an appt. on 11/11.  Already lined up 10 drivers in case I do it.  That's one blessing I've discovered, reconnecting with friends.  The friend who's gone to 2 chemos with me was my childhood friend.  Although she lives about 1-1/2 hrs. away, with traffic, it took her 3-1/2 yesterday.   We had a ball though, it was like being out with a friend, never knew I was in the chemo room and had no trouble with veins this time! Unique, so sorry about your H.  It must be so hard but like you say, it puts things in perspective.  My neighbor has brain cancer and lost her husband last year in a sudden industrial accident.  There is always someone worse off. TNT, your son must have been a very special person.  What a tribute to him.  I can't imagine losing my son.  A mother and son have such a special bond.  I can tell he is still such an inspiration to you.  Hunkering down for the weekend, usually the constipation kicks in and the headache already started.  Peeps
Posts.Title: Anyone starting chemo in October 08? SuzyWillKickThis unique

Posts.Content: Nov 17, 2008 10:41PM peeps1111 wrote: Kristi: I started taking sennecot and colace the day before chemo and I still ended up in the ER with bad constipation after my first TC.  The ER dr. said to add milk of magnesia to the mix after giving me an enema.  After the 2nd chemo I had even more problems despite taking all 3 of the above AND prunes, I did the enema myself,  so my oncologist precribed another drug, IC Enulose.  I took the enulose, the sennecot, the prunes and the colace and didn't have as many problems after the 3rd TC.  I take those things for about a week, then taper down one at a time.  Otherwise you can end up with diarrhea. Peeps
Posts.Title: Anyone starting chemo in October 08? SuzyWillKickThis unique

Posts.Content: Nov 18, 2008 11:22PM peeps1111 wrote: Hi Unique: I am going for the last TC on Thursday, hooray!  I can't wait for it to be over, then on to RADS, ugh.  Been doing a lot of research on that too.  My best friend from when I was a kid is coming down again to go to the chemo with me and we always have fun, it's like we're not even in the hospital. On the wig/hat issue, I'll chime in with voting for the hats.  I hate my wig, it's so uncomfortable and gives me a headache.  I only wear it if I shop locally or go to a restaurant.  I don't like people staring at me.  The other day I was in a store and was wearing a scarf and a woman came up to me and asked me if I was in the sisterhood. I said, "what?" She said, "do you have cancer?"  I said yes and she proceeded to tell me that she was wearing a wig.  So I guess not only does a turban  scream cancer, so does a scarf, lol.  I always have hats and scarves in the car because when my head gets hot in a hat, I like the scarves.  It's getting pretty cold here in the northeast though so hats are it for me.  I got a couple of free ones at the hospital.  One is a terrycloth turban that I wear to bed, so comfy.  I bought 3 at the dollar store and several more cheap at Target, and a couple of scarves at Bldg. 19 and a couple at headcovers.com.  Oddly enough, two of my friends said I look better with fuzz than hair, kind of a left-handed compliment, don't know what that says about my old hairdo.  The other day I was at the pool, got out of the shower and a cute little boy asked me if I was a girl, so funny.  One thing that's good is wearing a scarf or a turban when you're out helps people realize that chemo is doable, you can get on with your life. it lessens the fear.  I think some people have preconcieved notions that chemo is really horrible, much like it was years ago. Peeps
Posts.Title: Anyone starting chemo in October 08? SuzyWillKickThis unique

Posts.Content: Sep 26, 2008 01:20AM peeps1111 wrote: Praying Hand and Jenn46: Thanks for asking, I am much better physically today but had a meltdown this afternoon due to lack of sleep last night.  Woke up at 4a.m. and couldn't go back to sleep.  Had bloodwork today, see the onc tomorrow.  I am going to mention the insanity of giving us instructions to avoid crowds, people with colds, infections, etc., yet sending us to the ER with the sickest population for predictable side effect management, where is the common sense? Speaking of common sense, the wig store called, the wig was in so I went to get it, then the lady informed me that she couldn't style and fit it until I actually lost my hair.  Well, yeah, thanks for telling me before I drove all that way, duh.  I would have waited. Im wondering if there's anyone who hasn't lost their hair.  I read that 75% do. Food actually tasted good today.  Hope you are all feeling well tonight.  Peeps Dx 6/20/08, IDC, 1cm, DIC 1cm, 1/2 nodes, Grade 2/3, 20 oncotype test

Do you have any support system?  I am doing my 3rd on 10/30 so we will be in the chemo chair together. Peeps

Posts.Content: Feb 10, 2009 08:33PM peeps1111 wrote: Hi: Also have fibromyalgia and it did act up during rads.  I continued on and finished today.  I do water exercises which help and I hope I will get better.  I used the anti-anxiety meds that they gave me during chemo to help me sleep.  I also have bad tendonitis and use Motrin and/or hydrocodone. Posts.Title: radiation and fibromyalgia susiered Jknee54

Posts.Content: Sep 4, 2008 10:56AM peeps1111 wrote: Hi: I am in the same decision-making dilemma.  I had a sentinel node biopsy and 1 was positive and 1 was negative.  My onc did the oncotype dx test which came back with a score of 20 and she wants to do chemo, followed by radiation followed by hormonal therapy with Arimidex.  I am terrified of lymphedema and want to refuse the 2nd surgery.  I don't see the point of it if I am having chemo, radiation and hormonal therapy.   I've been seeking info about this for a while and they just keep saying it's the "standard of care". I am going for a 2nd opinion to Dana Farber next week. I know I'm stage 2 but I don't know the letter yet. I had a lumpectomy with the sentinel node biopsy on 7/30/08. Dx 6/20/08, IDC 1cm, Stage II, Grade 2, 1/2 nodes, ER+/PR-,HER2-
Posts.Title: Additional Lymph Node Surgery Alex517 HeatherBLocklear

Posts.Content: Feb 12, 2009 09:30AM peeps1111 wrote: Hi See: I've been wondering about that since I did rads.  You are not the 1st person to say their onc said to use nothing.  Some have had good luck with that.  I was told not to put anything on up to 4 hrs. before rads but other than that, I did my own thing.  Checked things out here and used Jean's Cream, then ALRA, then when I got burnt, I used emu oil and also My Girls Cream. To me, it defies common sense for them to burn your skin and tell you to use nothing.  Where are you being treated?
Posts.Title: no creams and lotion allowed during Radiations See Roya

Posts.Content: Feb 14, 2009 09:42AM peeps1111 wrote: Hi: I never blistered at all.  I just got red.  I went to Dana Farber in Boston.  I am one week out and my skin is great. Peeps
Posts.Title: no creams and lotion allowed during Radiations See Roya

Posts.Content: Nov 25, 2008 03:58PM peeps1111 wrote: Hi apfuentes: I can't help you with your decision but I just finished TC 4x and it is very doable.  Since you have young children, I think you will feel relieved when you're done.  Some side effects are uncomfortable and I'm grateful that I had only myself to take care of as my kids are grown but there were only a couple of days each time that were really a problem, constipation and a headache for two days.  Otherwise, I swam and/or walked 2 miles every day.  Food tasted bad sometimes but that's just annoying, didn't stop me from doing anything.  Although I have umpteen prescriptions here for nausea, I never needed them (wish I could donate them to someone without insurance). So don't be afraid, make your decision with conviction and don't look back.  Cancer is so unpredictable. For example, 30% of people with negative nodes end up with metastasis down the road.  So you just don't know.  Peeps
Posts.Title: Chemo or Not? apfuentes Seabee

Posts.Content: Mar 4, 2009 06:56PM peeps1111 wrote: Hi: I have fibromyalgia too.  The surgery didn't knock me out, I was at a wedding 3 days later but once I was finished with chemo, it came back with a vengeance.  It got worse and worse during radiation and I've been done for 3 weeks and I'm still suffering.  I hope the flare is gone soon.  I've had it for 20 yrs., got diagnosed in 1988.  At that time, most people had never heard of it and to this day, I still find it unbelievable that I can feel so bad and have nothing show up on any tests. Peeps
Posts.Title: Fibromyalgia = Pain barbe1958 barbe1958

Posts.Content: Sep 15, 2008 09:54PM peeps1111 wrote: Alex: What did your sister decide to do?  I had a 2nd opinion consult with a Boston oncologist who also recommended the 2nd surgery.  She said it was for "local" disease control.  She said you have to remove "gross" disease.  She said you either remove it or kill it (with radiation).  Since I'm having radiation to my right breast when I finish chemo, I decided to just have the axilla radiated instead of the surgery.  There is still a 5% chance of lymphedema from the radiation but I'll take my chances.  The micromet in my sentinel node was 1.9 mm.  Since I'm having chemo, radiation and hormone therapy, I feel that should kill any rogue cells.  I am comfortable with my decision.  Quality of life is a huge issue for me.  I am wondering what is the medical definition of "gross" disease is, like is it cancer no matter what the size?  I wish I had thought to ask.    Dx 6/20/08, IDC, 1cm, DCIS, 1 cm, Stage II?, Grade 2/3, 1/2 nodes, ER+,PR-/HER2-

Posts.Content: peeps1111 wrote: Hi: I'm so bummed out.  I went to RI Hospital today to see if I could get into the 3-week radiation program.  They said most likely no because of the positive sentinel node with the micrometastasis.  The thing that upsets me is that I told the dr. that when I talked about going there and they told me to come for the appt.  I knew that no one in the Canadian study had a positive node  but that is why I told the dr. about it before I went there.  Does anyone listen? They were going to present my caset to a group of drs this afternoon, but when I found out that they've never radiated anyone's axilla, I wouldn't want to be in it anyways because my biggest fear is lymphedema, not recurrence, and they said it may increase the risk of that with the stronger dose.  I'm already doing chemo, then radiation, then hormone therapy to prevent recurrence. Is there anyone else out there who refused the 2nd surgery (axilla nodes) and then did chemo and radiation to both the breast and the axilla?   Peeps   Dx 6/20/2008, IDC, 1cm, Stage IIA, Grade 2, 1/2 nodes, ER+/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Title: Getting ready to start Taxotere and Cytoxan Onehalf Onehalf

Posts.Content: Mar 3, 2009 06:53PM peeps1111 wrote: Hi: I also have type 2 diabetes.  I also recently read that people with high sugar are more susceptibe to cancer.  Makes me kick myself for resisting my dr.'s suggestion to take metformin.  I finally started taking it a couple of yrs. ago. I took a diabetes ed class at my local hospital and it was very informative.  I can't believe how many people out there still believe that diabetes happens because of eating too much sugar.  The most valuable piece of advice I got from the class was the #1 thing to read on a food label is "serving size".  The next thing is the carbs.  A good snack should have approximately 15 carbs and a good meal should have 45 carbs.  You can eat almost whatever you want but in small portions.  Do you have specific questions?  I adapted my stuffed cabbage recipe to incorporate ground turkey instead of beef, etc.  Pasta seems to raise my sugar more than anything else so I try to avoid it.  If I get chicken parm when I'm out to eat, I'll ask for a salad instead. Kashi cereal is really good for fiber in the morning.  You can subtract fiber from the carbs to get a true carb count. Thanks for starting this thread.  I walk every day for about 50 mins.  but could never do it without my walking buddy.  We motivate each other.  I swim every other day too.  There is always someone in the neighborhood who would walk with you, even if you're not really friends.  All you probably have to do is ask. Peeps

Posts.Title: Just diagnosed, should she take a trip? ebby ebby

Posts.Content: Oct 16, 2008 06:55AM peeps1111 wrote: Hi: This question is a sticking point for me too.  When I asked why they were still recommending the axillary node surgery after I had a micro-met in one of my sentinel nodes and if was having chemo, wouldn't that kill the cancer,  I was told by a Dana Farber oncologist that either removing or radiating the lymph nodes is necessary for local disease control.  I know chemo is systemic which I take to mean your whole system (doesn't that include local?)  so this still does not make sense to me and no one has been able to give me a plausible explanation other than "it's the standard of care". Because of this reason, I refused the 2nd surgery, am doing chemo but am left wondering why I have to do the radiation.  I am terrified of lymphedema.  I know there are things you can do to prevent it or help control it but I am all about quality of life.  Peeps
Posts.Title: Does chemo zap cancer in nodes... Lynette Maryiz

Posts.Content: Oct 26, 2008 03:36PM peeps1111 wrote: Nanova: You said, "the chemo and radiation should take care of any stray cancer cells - in the lymph nodes or wherever".  Is this your opinion or did your onc say this to you?  Also, are you having radiation to the axilla too or just the breast? lyn1117, interesting, because when I went for the 2nd opinion in Boston, I mentioned to the oncologist that I didn't have "vascular invasion" because I never saw anything about any lymphatic fluid or invasion on my report, and she said, "yes, you did".  So maybe I need to ask my onc about that too.  I would think that the chemo would take care of any cancer cells that "could move other places and start this process". I too believe this is kind of uncharted territory and since there was little response to this thread, I believe it is probably because when you sign the form for your sentinel node biopsy, you usually consent to the axillary node dissection if the cancer is found in the sentinel nodes at surgery.  Since only 20% is found after surgery at the final pathology, it gives us time to rethink the axillary node surgery. With the risk of lymphedema,  I think more patients are becoming educated and are questioning these procedures which don't make sense. Nanova, was it also your opinion that the dissection of the other nodes was unlikely to tell them anything else or was that also your dr.'s opinion? Peeps
Posts.Title: Does chemo zap cancer in nodes... Lynette Maryiz
